articles.headline: Wall Street Journal, Its Newsroom Unsettled, Names a New Editor
articles.snippet: During Gerard Baker’s tenure as editor in chief, the paper broke big stories and circulation rose — but he faced unrest in the newsroom.
articles.abstract: During Gerard Baker’s tenure as editor in chief, the paper broke big stories and circulation rose — but he faced unrest in the newsroom.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Wall Street Journal named a new editor in chief on Tuesday, elevating Matthew J. Murray to the top spot at one of the country’s pre-eminent newspapers and bringing an end to the tenure of Gerard Baker, whose stewardship gave rise to unrest in the newsroom.

articles.headline: Facebook Gave Data Access to Chinese Firm Flagged by U.S. Intelligence
articles.snippet: The company, Huawei, is one of at least four Chinese electronics businesses that have struck information-sharing agreements with the social network.
articles.abstract: The company, Huawei, is one of at least four Chinese electronics businesses that have struck information-sharing agreements with the social network.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facebook has data-sharing partnerships with at least four Chinese electronics companies, including a manufacturing giant that has a close relationship with China’s government, the social media company said on Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Michael LaForgia and Gabriel J.X. Dance

articles.headline: Goodbye, Swimsuit Competition. Hello, ‘Miss America 2.0.’
articles.snippet: In 1968, feminists threw bras and girdles into a trash can to protest the Miss America pageant for sexism. Now, #MeToo may have finally ushered in a new era.
articles.abstract: In 1968, feminists threw bras and girdles into a trash can to protest the Miss America pageant for sexism. Now, #MeToo may have finally ushered in a new era.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago, the swimsuit-wearing beauties of the Miss America pageant were confronted with a spectacle on the Atlantic City boardwalk: 100 feminists throwing bras, girdles, curling irons, false eyelashes and other “instruments of female torture” into a trash can labeled “Freedom.”

articles.headline: Greece May Be Turning a Corner. Greeks Who Fled Are Staying Put.
articles.snippet: Greece is reaching a pivotal moment as it prepares to exit financial bailouts. Greeks who left the country are skeptical.
articles.abstract: Greece is reaching a pivotal moment as it prepares to exit financial bailouts. Greeks who left the country are skeptical.
articles.lead_paragraph: DÜSSELDORF, Germany — After a decade of economic pain, Greece finally appears to be back on track. Try telling that to the Greeks who left and have no plans to return, like Constantine Kakoyiannis.

articles.headline: Gavin Newsom and John Cox to Compete in California Election for Governor
articles.snippet: The candidates, who edged out the former Los Angeles mayor Antonio Villaraigosa, are likely to battle over President Trump this fall. Democrats were in tight races in several Republican-held House districts.
articles.abstract: The candidates, who edged out the former Los Angeles mayor Antonio Villaraigosa, are likely to battle over President Trump this fall. Democrats were in tight races in several Republican-held House districts.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Gavin Newsom, the Democratic lieutenant governor and former mayor of San Francisco, took a major step Tuesday in his bid to become California’s next governor, capturing one of two spots on the November ballot as the state moved closer to the end of the era of Gov. Jerry Brown.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: A Russian Oligarch’s $500 Million Yacht Is in the Middle of Britain’s Costliest Divorce
articles.snippet: Stranded in Dubai, the 377-foot Luna is fought over by a Russian oligarch who refuses to hand over a penny to his ex-wife.
articles.abstract: Stranded in Dubai, the 377-foot Luna is fought over by a Russian oligarch who refuses to hand over a penny to his ex-wife.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — With a spa, a swimming pool, two heliports and room for 18 guests, the Luna is more like a floating luxury villa than a yacht. A crew of 50 keep all nine decks in pristine shape. The lifeboats cost $4 million apiece. Gleaming engines propel the vessel at a maximum speed of 22 knots.

articles.headline: Bush Scion Is Out as Health Firm’s Chief After Intense Activist Campaign
articles.snippet: Jonathan Bush, a nephew and cousin of presidents and the founder of Athenahealth, which provides digital services to medical offices, resigned under pressure by the hedge fund Elliott Management.
articles.abstract: Jonathan Bush, a nephew and cousin of presidents and the founder of Athenahealth, which provides digital services to medical offices, resigned under pressure by the hedge fund Elliott Management.
articles.lead_paragraph: A member of one of America’s best-known political families resigned on Wednesday from the health care technology company he started more than two decades ago, in a victory for one of the world’s most powerful hedge funds.
articles.byline: By Kate Kelly and David Enrich

articles.headline: Paul Ryan Dismisses Trump ‘Spy’ Charge as G.O.P. Shows Signs of Resistance
articles.snippet: Speaker Paul D. Ryan backed Representative Trey Gowdy in dismissing President Trump’s assertion that the F.B.I. inserted a “spy” into his campaign.
articles.abstract: Speaker Paul D. Ryan backed Representative Trey Gowdy in dismissing President Trump’s assertion that the F.B.I. inserted a “spy” into his campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker Paul D. Ryan contradicted President Trump’s assertions of a broad conspiracy by federal law enforcement on Wednesday, joining other lawmakers in saying that the F.B.I. did nothing wrong by using a confidential informant to contact members of the Trump campaign as it investigated its ties to Russia.
